PAST AND FUTURE OF THE RIGHT OF NATIONAL SELF-DETERMINATION BY & DE GOOIJER HOFLEVERANCIERS.

Indische ^SV Tel. Int 174 DEBONT&LEYTEN'8 FIJNE CHOCOLADE EN SU1KERWERKEN a. b. c. DR. ERNÖWITTMANN ADVOCATE BUDAPEST
WITH 2 MAP S. CONTENT SCHAPTER I.
THE ACTION OF WILL AN OBJECT OK LAW. a. Process leading to Actlon. Róle of Memory in the Process. Will, a Reflex influenced by Memories. b. Our own Peicepiions of the Will and the Actual Event. c. Masses. Mind and Will of Masses.
CHAPTER II.
FOREIGN POLICY OF THE FRENCH GOVERNMENT DURINQ THE REVO LUT10N. a. Recognition of Self-Determination in Theory. b. Realization f Traditions of French Forelgn Policy in Practice.
CHAPTER III. CRITICISM OF THE RULES OF INTERNATIONAL LAW RELATING TC NATIONAL SELF-DETERMINATION. The Rlght of National Self-Determlnation under Napoleon Ui Theories of the State's Origin. Röle of Popular Movement and of Army in the Formation oi Slates. Can the Röle of the Army in the Formation of States be replaced by the Work of an International Organ ? Common Characteristics of the Jugo-Slav, Czech-SIovak and Roumanian Movements.
ANNEX TO CHAPTER III.
CLAIMS OF NATIONALITIES TO HUNGARIAN TERRITORY a. Aim of Roumanians, Dacia, of Czecho-Slovaks, GreatMoravia and of Serbs, Ihe Patriarchale of Pek; and of all these Nationaliiies, Boundaries dominating Hungarian Territoty. . The Division of Hungary according to Ethnographical Boun
daries results in parts which cannot exlst separately.
CHAPTER IV.
THE TASK OF THE PEACE-CONFERENCE. Hls and Remedies. a. Vienna Congress of 1814. b. Taylor's System applied to Politics. c. The Function of Boundaries. The Historical Boundaries of Hungary. Boundaries of the Czecho-Slovak State, and of Roumania. Wsy to the Adriatic. d. Constitutions. International Court as Guarantee of the Conslitutlonal Rights of Nationalities. NOTES. MAPS. 1. Hungary and its Naticnalities. 2. Claims of Nationalities to Hungarian Territory.
